Levels.Description: Levels contain everything a player can see and interact with, such as environments, objects, characters, etc.
Levels.Definition: A Level is part of your game's world, containing everything visible and interactive. Multiple levels usually have transitions, like progressing after defeating a boss.
Levels.FileFormat: Unreal Engine saves each Level as a separate .umap file, sometimes referred to as Maps.

Components.Description: The Level itself, a container holding everything else.
Environmental fixtures like trees, rocks, and walls.
One or more lights of different types.
Ambient sounds and sound effects, e.g., footsteps.

LearnMore.Description: How to create, save, and open level assets.
Use the Levels window to manage your persistent level and sublevels.
Set the default editor and game Levels for your project.

Community.Purpose: Ask questions and help your peers.

WorkingWithLevels.Description: How to create, save, and open level assets.
WorkingWithLevels.Storage: Levels are stored in individual Asset files with special considerations.

Methods: Right-click in Content Browser: Create Basic Asset > Level
Keyboard shortcut: Ctrl + N (Windows) or Cmd + N (Mac)

Templates: Open World: Sample content with World Partition feature.
Empty Open World: Uses World Partition without content.
Basic: Includes floor plane, lighting, atmosphere, and fog.
NewLevelWindow.Action: Select the desired template and click Create. The new Level opens automatically.

CreatingLevels.SourceControl: New Levels are automatically added to source control when created and saved.

Methods: Main menu: File > Save Current Level
Keyboard shortcut: Ctrl + S (Windows) or Cmd + S (Mac)
SavingLevels.FirstSave: Specify name and folder in Save Level As window.
SaveCopy: Main menu: File > Save Current Level As
Keyboard shortcut: Ctrl + Alt + S (Windows) or Cmd + Option + S (Mac)
SavingLevels.Prompt: Changing Levels will prompt to save current Level(s).

Methods: Main menu: File > Open Level and select Level
Keyboard shortcut: Ctrl + O (Windows) or Cmd + O (Mac)

ManagingMultipleLevels.Description: Use the Levels window to manage persistent levels and sublevels.
ManagingMultipleLevels.Context: For Unreal Engine 4 legacy projects or non-game projects. For Unreal Engine 5.0+, World Partition replaces the Levels window.

Steps.PersistentLevel: Always present, with one or more sublevels.
Steps.VisibilityNote: Visibility changes are for visualization only and do not affect streaming into the game.

Methods: Split from existing Level or sublevel
AddingNewSublevels.MakeCurrentNote: New sublevels become the current Level. Right-click to switch back to previous level.

Steps: Select and open Level in Open Level dialog
Select save location and name, then Save
Select Actors to move in Scene Outliner or Viewport
Click Levels dropdown > Create New with Selected Actors
Select save location and name, then Save
SplittingOffSublevels.Note: Selected Actors are moved to new sublevel.

Steps: Select Actors to move in Scene Outliner or Viewport
Right-click a Level in the Levels window, select Move Selected Actors to Level
Press Ctrl+S to save all Levels

LevelDetails.Description: Access additional information about Levels. Set Level Streaming Volumes and other settings.
LevelDetails.PersistentLevels: No additional details, but can change to another Level.

Steps: Set sublevel color in Levels window or Level Details window
Toggle level color: Show button > Advanced > Level Coloration
Persistent level shown in white, sublevels in selected colors
Works in perspective and orthographic viewports, toggled off with Game Mode

WorldSettings.Description: The World Settings panel is where you set and override Level-specific settings.
WorldSettings.Access: Main menu: Window > World Settings. Docks next to the Details panel.
WorldSettings.Usage: Specify settings for the current Level using the Search box to quickly find settings.

SettingsGroups.Description: Reduces rendering thread time at the cost of runtime memory, optimizing performance for smaller levels.
Select and configure Game Mode for current Level, defining game rules.
Specify Lightmass settings for indirect lighting and ambient occlusion.
Core aspects like level bounds, navigation systems, and Actor destruction depth.
Override World Gravity and specify advanced physics settings.
Settings for Broadphase collision using NVIDIA's PhysX system.
Enable Hierarchical Levels of Detail (HLODs) for performance optimization.

SettingsGroups.Group: World Partition Setup and World Partition
SettingsGroups.Description: Data management and distance-based level streaming for large world management.
Configure the navigation grid for your Level.
Adjust the scale of your virtual world with the World to Meters variable.
Settings for distance field ambient occlusion and dynamic indirect shadows.
Configure default sound behaviors like volume, reverb, and fade time.
Enable or disable per-frame Tick() update function for Actors or Components.
Enable Unreal Engine 4's Artificial Intelligence system.
Settings for building and deploying your game to different platforms.

ChangingDefaultLevel.Description: How to set the default editor and game Levels for your project.

Steps.Action: Click on the Edit menu and select Project Settings.
Project Settings will open your project's settings.
Click on Maps & Modes in the left panel.
Click the dropdown arrow next to Game Default Map and select the desired Level.
Click the dropdown arrow next to Editor Startup Map to change it if desired.

AdvancedSettings.Description: In Default Maps, you can set Local Map Options, a Transition Map, and a Server Default Map.
